facts.text: Appellant arrested on 31st March 1967 at about 9.30 p.m. in State Transport Corporation Workshop at Naroda, Ahmedabad, while working in Baroda Central State Transport Workshop.

Charge framed on 21-9-1967: Accused is foreigner from Pakistan, permitted to stay till 20th September 1958 by permit No. 19904 dated 6-12-1957, failed to depart, contravened clause 7(iii) of Foreigners Order 1948, offence under Section 14 Foreigners Act 1946.
Accused produced Pakistani passport Ex.11 dated 8th September 1955; came to India in 1955 on it.
Accused made visa application to High Commissioner for India in Pakistan on 10th October 1955, stating he migrated from India to Pakistan in 1950.
Accused born at Dhandhuka, Gujarat on 15th May 1936; lived there and attended school until 1952; then moved to Ahmedabad with father.

Accused went to Pakistan as minor in state of anger after quarrel with father who drove him out; denied intention to settle; regretted within six months and tried to return but needed Pakistani passport.
Judicial Magistrate acquitted respondent, holding he proved Indian citizenship and never migrated to Pakistan.
Gujarat High Court upheld acquittal on 3rd/4th December 1969 in Criminal Appeal No. 295 of 1966; found respondent Indian citizen on 26th January 1950 and minor when visited Pakistan.

legal_issues.text: Whether respondent was a foreigner who contravened clause 7(iii) Foreigners Order 1948 by overstaying permit, or an Indian citizen whose citizenship status post-26th January 1950 required determination under Section 9 Citizenship Act 1955.
Whether courts have jurisdiction to decide if respondent, an Indian citizen on 26th January 1950, voluntarily acquired Pakistani citizenship after that date.
Whether respondent migrated to Pakistan before 26th January 1950.

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondent is Pakistani national who migrated to Pakistan, obtained Pakistani passport, entered India on it, and overstayed permit; clause 3 Schedule III Citizenship Rules 1956 provides passport as conclusive proof of acquiring foreign citizenship.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 14 Foreigners Act 1946; clause 7(iii) Foreigners Order 1948; Section 9 Citizenship Act 1955; clause 3 Schedule III Citizenship Rules 1956

petitioner_arguments.text: Courts have jurisdiction to decide if accused is foreigner; acquittal improper without deciding post-1950 citizenship acquisition.

respondent_arguments.text: Indian citizen on 26th January 1950; never migrated to Pakistan; went temporarily as minor in 1953-54 without intent to settle; passport and visa statements false to obtain documents.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Articles 5, 7 Constitution of India; Section 9 Citizenship Act 1955

court_reasoning.text: Lower courts correctly found respondent Indian citizen on 26th January 1950 and went to Pakistan after as minor; prosecution case not confined to pre-1950 migration.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prosecution failed to prove migration before Constitution; question of post-1950 citizenship acquisition under Section 9 Citizenship Act for Central Government.

court_reasoning.text: Courts lack jurisdiction to decide if Indian citizen post-1950 voluntarily acquired foreign citizenship; must leave to Central Government; improper to convict or acquit without such determination.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Charge requires determining if respondent was foreigner at time of entry/overstay; exclusive to Central Government.

court_reasoning.text: Quash charge and discharge as prosecution proceeded erroneously without prior Central Government decision.
court_reasoning.key_observation: State free to reprosecute after appropriate authority decision.

holdings.text: Criminal courts cannot decide under Section 9 Citizenship Act if person citizen on 26th January 1950 later voluntarily acquired foreign citizenship; must defer to Central Government.
Acquittal set aside not on merits but due to jurisdictional error; charge quashed, accused discharged.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kulathil Mammu v. State of Kerala
precedents_cited.relevance: Migration under Article 7 has wider meaning than domicile; exceptions where migration does not occur.

precedents_cited.case_name: Smt. Shanno Devi v. Mangal Sain
precedents_cited.relevance: View on migration overruled by Kulathil Mammu.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh v. Abdul Khader
precedents_cited.relevance: Section 9 Citizenship Act determination by Central Government.

precedents_cited.case_name: Abdul Sattar v. State of Gujarat
precedents_cited.relevance: Section 9 Citizenship Act determination by Central Government.

precedents_cited.case_name: Akbar Khan v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Courts must stay proceedings if post-1950 citizenship question arises; defer to Central Government.

statutes_cited.name: Foreigners Act 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: Offence of contravening stay permit; burden of proof on foreigner.

statutes_cited.name: Citizenship Act 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Central Government determines voluntary acquisition of foreign citizenship post-26th January 1950.

statutes_cited.name: Citizenship Rules 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Passport as conclusive proof of foreign citizenship acquisition.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; acquittal by trial court and High Court set aside; charge quashed; respondent discharged. State may reprosecute after Central Government decision under Section 9 Citizenship Act.

key_quotes.text: "the question whether a person voluntarily acquired the citizenship of Pakistan during the specified period, could only be determined by the Central Government."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on jurisdictional limits of courts.

key_quotes.text: "the proper thing to do for a Court where the question arises is to refuse to adjudicate on that question."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Directs procedure when citizenship issue under Section 9 arises.

key_quotes.text: "We also quash the charge framed against the respondent and order that he be discharged."
key_quotes.speaker: court
